description:
This is authentic Salvadorean food. Not a fancy place at all.  But good food. May take a little time but good food. Parking? forget it; hard to get in a busy area of the mission, but good food. 

Atole de Elote: Yummy!!
Pupusa's. very good. 
Sopa deRes... true beef soup with chunk of everything!!
author: shirley c.

description:
Food was good. I liked the food.

I did not like the cashier, who stole money from us at this cash only joint when trying to pay. When confronted by person and witness, she denied it. It was a noticeable $10 missing... from a bill that was questionably rounded on to begin with.

Environment looks like something that would receive a D grade on health review, but you expect that from the front anyways.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Pupusa's are delicious here! Definately worth the try. This as the first place that I have ever had pupusas and this place was my standard. I really love how cirspy and fresh the tortilla and fillings were. My favorite ones to order are the cheese and bean as well as the shredded pork. The pork is absolutely delicious as it is tender and juicy. The cheese and bean pupusa is really delicious and the ratio from cheese to bean is perfect. Also the salad/garnish it comes with is delicious. Just having that alone as a side dish is honestly perfect to me. I wish it had more kick to it (spicy). 

One thing that I have to mention is be careful if you're vegetarian/vegan because they cook their beans in lard. I believe there is an alternative where you can ask for black beans instead of refried beans, but again it is best to ask. 

Another special mention on the menu is to get their horchata. It is seriously tasty and it will lighten up your day. Everyone loves a good horchata drink!

In terms of food and service it is pretty good. Sometimes the wait for the food can be long , but for the most part on average it comes in around 10-15 min. 

If you're ever in the neighborhood or in the mood for pupusas I'd say this place is a must. It is also right outside the bus stop so it's super easy to get to.
author: John M.

description:
Consistently the best pupusas I've ever had. The masa is always soft and fresh and gets crispy around the edges in the grill. They are always made to order, generous with fillings and never doughy. With the curtido and red sauce, a highly delicious and inexpensive meal.
Remember, they are made to order, so be prepared to wait 10 or 15 min for takeout orders (or call in).
author: Mary S.

description:
Ordered some Salpicon ( to go ) & payed $12.50 for that amount of Salpicon. It's so unbelievable man. Definitely should be ashamed of yourselves . I've ordered some In the past but never to the point where I get this little amount . 

The pupusas are decent. Last time I ordered only pupusas and out of the 12 i got,  3 of them were tortillas. 

I really enjoyed coming here as it was super close to my house ( parking sucks tho' ) but that was such a rip off . I always call them when they messed up my orders but man this sh** was the last draw .
author: Veronica N.

description: Good but they take hella long and expensive .  4 stars just for pupusas.  They are always busy and no parking ever.
author: Joe B.

description: Good pupusas. Average price for the area. The plates are a bit expensive though and not worth it.
author: Andrew R.

description: Had the pupusas revueltas and they were amazing. Cooked to order and inexpensive. Cash only though.
author: Kathleen C.

description: Been coming here for a very long time.  Always eat pupusa de queso con loroco my all time favorite.  Very delicious the ladies that work here are so friendly .  This location looks small when you enter only having three tables but there is more seating upstairs.
author: Daniel C.

description:
My favorite Salvi place to eat. The pupusas, plátanos, frijoles, empanadas and atole de elote are on point! 
The ensalada drink is delicious (light type of punch with fruit pieces). The tamarindo... perfect balance of sweet and tart. The pupusas are not greasy and a generous size, two full you up real quick. Love the food here! 
Service takes a little while but it's worth it. The women that work there are polite but do not flower you with attention. It's more focused on the quality of food.
author: Melissa M.

description: Horrible service, I asked for a beef tongue and the dish was not served as the menu description and asked to change the dish Bc of that and they were so rude and even didn't ask if I want something else. I tried one pupusa and was good.
author: Nelly P.

description:
This ranks very high on my list of pupuserias to date. My best friend has been coming here since she was small, so to me, that's already a mix of "delicious childhood food" and "well, she hasn't steered me wrong yet".

I don't know how people rank "best" whenever I read these reviews. I will say that so far, based on my Pupusa Spreadsheet, this is currently ranking at the top based on several factors. (I have a problem.)

The main things that make these pupusas tasty include a good masa-to-insides ratio, SUPER tasty chicharrones, cooked perfectly with lots of crisp areas with the yummy crispy cheese, delightful loroco, and salsa that I think I'd drink straight up if someone asked me to.

Price is on point at $2.50 a pop at the time of this review. Cash only. Yelp says it's closed on Sunday, but I dunno...I was there on a Sunday, so I have no idea what's going on!
author: Robbin A.

description:
The short version..
GOOD: Btwn this Pupuseria & the adjacent bakery, I've found my Salvadorian fix! :)
BAD: I see weight gain in my future O_o

The long version..
FOOD - Pupusa are fried thick corn tortillas with fillings quite similar to arepas. The pupusas at Los Planes De Renderos are deliciously flavorful, nice & cheesy, and the exterior is not greasy. 

An order of pupusa comes with a side of curtido (cabbage slaw) and homemade salsa. I tried 3 different ones and they well all quite good!
- Pupusa de Chicharron y Queso (shredded pork + cheese) - my favorite!
- Pupusa Revuelta (shredded pork + cheese + beans) - a bit salty
- Pupusa de Queso y Loroco (cheese + loroco) - Interesting since I didn't know what loroco was but had ordered it because it was recommended. Loroco is an edible flower. It's good, I just prefer meat filling :P

AMBIANCE - As other yelpers have commented, this place is a bit dive-y. When you step in there are 3 small tables and a partial view of the kitchen. There's a stairway that leads to more seating on the 2nd floor. While the interior may not be impressive, the food will more than make up for it. It's often these mom & pop shops that have the most authentic food so order yours to go.

SERVICE - I called ahead to place an order and it was ready in 20min. The lady who took my order was friendly and gave me recommendations on their popular pupusas.

PARKING - a bit difficult to find parking but the food is well worth the hassle

TIPS -
- CASH ONLY!
- Check out the Salvadorian bakery next door -- good pastries especially the tres leche!
author: Ruby C.

description: Delicious pupusas revueltas!!! Also our go to is simply frijoles y queso. Their tamales are good as are their plátanos fritos. Great for dine in or takeout. Bring cash. Their curtido is on point. Yum. Now I'm hungry for pupusas.
author: Beth C.

description:
I finally had my first pupusa at Los Planes De Renderos Pupuseria. And I loved it! My friend brought me here and applauded that this place has the best pupusas in the city. And she's right! Their pupusas are delicious, with the right amount of filling and texture. We shared and ordered 3 pupusas with queso (cheese) and loroco, along with horchata (housemade). They also serve free chips & salsa. This whole meal cost under $10, which is such a great deal. 
So, I'd you are craving pupusas or want to try out a pupusa for the first time like I did, come to this place!
author: Vivian L.

description: It might not be the best pupusaria, but still it's a damn hella good pupusa spot. Pupusas here are always crisp on the outside and tender on the inside. The revuelto pupupsa is the best here!! It's a must eat. Also, CASH only. Very casual spot
author: Jan R.

description: Pupusas revueltas. So delicious! Thicker and more filling than other places. Parking can be a challenge. Can't wait to go back to try tamale, empanadas , pasteles and plantains.
author: Elaine S.

description: The pupusas here are delicious. They offer an extensive variety like cheese, bean and cheese, pork cheese and beans, zucchini and cheese and cheese and lorocco. They are a good size and have generous fillings, however, the restaurant isn't very attractive. It's very small and cramped. There are only 3 tables downstairs. I understand there is an upstairs where there are more tables but since I ordered to go I didn't go up there. They are chintzy with the cabbage salad. Please provide enough cabbage salad for the number of pupusas your customers order. They also packed some red sauce but they put it in a plastic bag instead of a container for liquids. The bag looked like a red balloon about to pop. I found this awkward and unappealing. So, I threw it away. Please put it in an appropriate container. They only take cash.
author: Review L.

description: Traveled all the way from Antioch just to satisfy my pupusa craving! The best indeed.
author: Leandra G.

description: I thought this place would be better than it was.  With so many other pupuserias in the neighborhood, you're better off exploring and taking a chance on another one.  I was most put off by a peculiar odor in the downstairs dining area.  I was reminded of the funky smells from the men's locker room at my gym.  The place has character though.
author: Lucullus L.

description:
Cash only, neighborhood hole in the wall place. 
Good for take out. Good price .
author: Pran R.

description: Pupusas are great! My favorite is the been and cheese. Yuca is good  for an appetizer. It's a welcoming atmosphere and the service is friendly.
author: Amir M.

description:
Growing up Salvadorian, I use to come to eat here a lot when I was little with my family. Recently, I visited again and can say that the majority of the food is the real thing. Although the food is good, I have to give two stars because I really believe this restaurant is unsanitary for many reasons. 
1. As soon as I walked in there was an odor of sewer water 

2. Going upstairs it is clear they do not dust or properly clean/upkeep the restaurant (I mean, they had those ceiling fan lamps from the early 90's and it was filled with dust) 

3. They clean the table with Clorox, it's a tight space restaurant so when they spray I feared for my life that Little particles of it would be in my food and I would be poisoned. 

4. Service is pretty terrible 

How does this restaurant have an 86??

(excuse my spanglish) pero me dio asco venir aquí.

I think take out might be a better option because their pupusas, pastelitos, empanadas, and atole de elote are some of my favorites
author: Anielle G.

description:
I love love love their pupusa's !!! 

The restaurant is getting a little run down, but their food is OMG amazing! 

Pupusa's made out of rice flour and stuffed with beans and cheese... Yuuummo!!! 
Plátanos fritos, fresco de marallon, empanadas, sopa de pollo, atol de elote...
You name it!!! It's all delicious
author: Diana R.

description:
The first time I had pupusas from this place was when i ordered 40 for work. First off the pupusas are DELICIOUS!! Not greasy like others I have had. The staff is friendly and the price is so affordable!

Today I went with my hubby for lunch and he really enjoyed it. We both ordered the combo plate with 2 pupusas, rice, and beans. The beans and rice are so yummy!!!

I can't wait to go back :) Two combo plates, two drinks and tip was $22.00.
author: Audra M.

description:
These ladies need to step up their crap attitude. Poor service day in and day out , over the phone and in person. I checked the health score today, they were graded a little over a week ago. A solid 84, on a big red poster. Dirty looking and now we know they have dirty food. 

On a positive note, regardless of what's in the pupusas, they are pretty delicious, so they earn themselves 2 stars in my opinion.
author: Antonio P.

description: i ordered two atoles de elote, they added water in the one to fill the cup one was thick and rich and the other was like water, could of just said they only had one cup left...
author: Josue R.

description: This is probably one of the worst places I've been to eat with my family. First of all we ordered ahead of time and they gave us our food really late and we had to wait long periods of time in between each plate we got. Secondly they messed up our orders and we had to order more food in person after the orders came in. And lastly the food was flavorless and bland it was really nothing special to start with. And at the end of the day I regret coming here for food.
author: Jethsamany P.

description: Love this place! I grew up in the neighborhood so I've been eating here for many years. Best Pupusas north of El Salvador in my humble opinion! My 2nd and 3rd favorite dishes are the Yucca Frita con Chicharron and Carne Deshilada (Shredded Beef) with rice and beans. What this place lacks in decor, it makes up with delicious food!
author: Gustav A.

description:
This is the spot to go to when you want pupusas. I have been coming here for years whether it's eating in their upstairs area listenibg to some cumbia or ordering ahead of time for pick up.  

They are made to order and are delicious. I usually get pupusas revueltas de maiz (corn flour, beans,shredded pork and cheese) i can eat 2 of those and I am stuffed! Complete this with some curtido (pickled cabbage) and salsa and you're set!

The pastel is really good too which is like a turnover filled with delicious meat inside ..just typing this is making me drool.... make sure you bring cash because its cash only.
If you're feeling spontaneous and want a salvadorian drink try the ensalada drink which has green apple,red apple,little bits of lettuce,marañon,mango, and mamey. Sooo good/LOTS OF FLAVOR!
author: Jennifer R.

description: Whenever we crave for papusa this is would our spot! Always super yummy and never long wait...
author: Jennie C.

description:
This hole in the wall pupusa specialist makes basic corn and rice flour pupusas to order. There aren't many pupusa varieties, just variations of shredded pork (chicharron), cheese, refried beans and lorroco. They also have tacos, empanadas, and Salvadorean tamales. 

I waited about 15 minutes for my pupusas to be made. There wasn't much décor to look at or seating downstairs, so I recommend going to the Salvadorean bakery (Pacitas Bakery) next door.

* Pupusa revuelta ($1.85 each): Flavorful but greasy corn pupusa filled with creamy beans, pork and cheese and slaw and hot sauce on the side. The cabbage slaw is slightly spicy, crunchy and tangy. Fulfills the pupusa craving but it's basic and greasy.

Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Best Atol de Elote! Sweet, Creamy and the perfect amount of corn kernels!

My fave pupusas (Staying away from Pork) are the Loroco, Cheese and Bean Pupusas!!

Their "ensalada" drink ( not a salad) that they serve on the weekends is a refreshing fresh fruit drink that has Salvadorean fruit and flavors! YUM

Empanadas de leche! ( Dessert) Definitely worth the cheat meal! 

Ive been coming here since 2002! Still my favorite place in SF
author: Gina S.

description: Good pupusas and customer service, the ladies at the registers are really nice ! Prices are fair
author: Hermes L.

description: This is the place I go to when I'm craving a pupusa! I would have gave them 5 starts but last time I dined my pupusa's were extremely soggy compared to how they were at previous times.
author: Alexi K.

description:
Well yes, it's a pupusa. It's not just a pupusa, but it is a thick, hot deliciousness of cheese, beans and chicharron. At least that is the one I ordered. With a cabbage slaw that was on the side with a lightness to it that fit right in. It left room to not overpower the pupusa itself. Top it with their homemade salsa and dig in. I did indeed order a pupusa and I ordered a tamale. The pupusa had done it and I had to take the tamale to go. However, as I waited for BART 4 hours later, I devoured it with a sense of pure happiness.
I will absolutely hit this hole in the wall again.
Well done Los Planes De Renderos!
author: Jaynie F.

description:
Pupusas. Made with Love.

I want to gain a healthy 5-10 lbs to counter balance my speedy metabolism. Yes, I've tried the weight gainers and some bulking techniques but I want to do it more naturally. If I don't eat something 2 hours prior to sleep, I'll be STARVING, drop a good couple of pounds in weight overnight and wake up to 6-pack abs by sunrise. If I overeat, I'll have zero appetite in the morning, still drop a few pounds and go binge-eating by the afternoon. It seems very unreachable especially since fast food is out of the question, and with my metabolism always in overdrive. 

That's why I decided to hop on a Latin diet. Who doesn't love the exotic flavors and fresh ingredients of Latin America? And let's not forget my favorite day of the week, Taco Tuesdays! That's where Los Planes de Renderos falls in. This Excelsior district Salvadoran hole-in-the-wall serves up some of the better Latin eats around, with a nack for homemade Pupusas. 

Taco De Pollo $4 - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/5q4iWQKGIcFl6KfyWEI7-A?select=y114RxyF51alXRsGJBd6CA
It was a ton of wholesome grilled chicken smothered in tomatoy hot sauce, fused with rice and refried beans and toppled all on a warm corn tortilla. Oh, and there was also a salad (whatever). The chicken was soft, tender, and succulent with the hot sauce giving a distinct kick of flavor to each bite. It was a very messy victory. 

Pupusa de Chicharron y Queso $2 per - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/5q4iWQKGIcFl6KfyWEI7-A?select=HZqcse-Uuo87swyKvkYgpA
With a wide variety of different pupusas all for a measly $2 each, my girlfriend and I opted for the shredded pork and cheese. All pupusa orders are served with their house concoction salsa rojo and a cabbage slaw. Each pupusa was the side of a huge oversize pancake.  The shredded pork was evenly distributed with the ooey gooey cheesy goodness webbing through interior. Top it with the slaw and add the salsa to adjust to your spiciness liking, these things are simply bomb!

Los Planes de Renderos Pupuseria is special. Not just because they have the longest name I've ever seen and my inability to roll my "R's" doesn't serve it justice but this hole-in-the-wall has heart. There's only the owner and the chef running the show here and it does get surprisingly busy. The owner kindly takes your order while the chef is flipping dozens of pupusas on the grill, like a boss. It's not about making an extra buck or caring about having the better dining experience here but about serving homemade-to-order great food to the community at dirt cheap prices so that everybody may enjoy. Remember Sam Wo, everybody? Kind owner, fast service, great authentic food, all without breaking the bank. 

Cash only and don't forget to order a Horchata!
author: Albert L.

description: I like the place ,  very clean and they provide great customer service .  I have been there few times and they provide a delicious food.  Just a heads up, the place most of them busy
author: Moaid M.

description:
Best pupusas ever. 

I found that most chicharron pupusas are extremely salty, but the pork in theirs is incredibly tasty and tender.  I'd recommend zucchini amazing cabbage and salsa.  It did take awhile for our order to come, but it was definitely worth the wait.  It must be difficult for those women to walk up and down the stairs constantly with huge orders of food so I commend them.
author: Jodie L.

description: The popusas and Atol de elote is good too; however the service needs improvement.  My father had to go downstairs to ask for a waiter. Really slow service.  Only come here if you have time.
author: Francisca C.

description: The Pupusas here are great!!! I've been to other places and their Pupusas are not as authentic as the ones in here. The cheese is actually pretty good and their salsa is bomb too. The costumer service is not the best but I can't complain either.
author: Alejandra V.

description: I agree their pupusas are good but the kitchen & waitresses need to have better comunication between them. My uncle oredered an extra pupsa revelta & we never got it at our table much less to go. I ordered 4 pupusas de queso to go & the other waitress took them & served them at her table & they wanted me to wait 10 minutes because of their mistake & lack of comunication. Sopa de maricos sucked, siete mares at Reinas is the bomb. chicaron needed some flavor. nuegados tasted like flour not yuca or cheese they looked like zeppoli italian donuts or beignets french donuts
author: Nancy R.

description: Food fresh and good but service lacks and needs improvement. If you're not local they seem to ignore you...so thats why I give them only 3 total for food and service
author: Kay D.

description: Pupusas de arroz. A unique variation of the pupusa that they have perfected. Seating is limited, downstairs. Plenty of seating upstairs!
author: Jeanine M.

description: Love the pupusas! The best I've ever had!! Great service and good prices. Will definitely be coming back here.
author: Nicole O.

description:
This place is tiny tiny well from when you walk in but I think they have an upstairs. I've always walked past this place and finally had the time to go in and it was well worth it. 

We started off with some horchata 
And it was pretty good not some of the best I've ever had but still pretty good and refreshing. 

We got the papausas and enchiladas and they were both really good. 

The chicken enchiladas were super cheesy and the chicken was really moist

I like this spot I'll be back
author: christina a.

description:
If you are looking for advice on a good pupusa place....ask someone from El Salvador. 

When you get there and all you see are other Salvadorians you know you're at a good place.

There is nothing fancy about this place but there is very good food. For $1.75 you can get one of the better pupusas I have had in SF (and I have had hundreds of pupusas in LA and SF). 

I went here and ordered: 

4 pupusas (entree)
1 order or empanadas (dessert)
2 horchatas (drinks)
1 tamal (appetizer)

All for...less than $20. An awesome deal for dinner for two. 

This place has about 4 tables on the ground level and much more seating upstairs.
author: Carlos A.

description: Authentic to the bone n masa. This place doesn't serve alcohol n is not known in the Excelsior for the service.. The Food!!! Makes this place a steady go to for authentic Salvadoren cuisine ..
author: B A.

description:
This was my first time having pupusas, and it was BOMB.  I highly recommend this place.  Food is hot, fresh, delicious, filing, tasty.  I have no negatives.  I also recommend having this drink called-cola champagne, which I didn't have, but apparently goes with the meal really well.  

GO GO GO and then hit the bakery up next door.
author: Aly A.

description:
People sometimes say "It's not just food, it's about atmosphere," and usually I think they're wrong because if I'm in a restaurant I'm there to eat. I'll go to a museum if I want to appreciate my surroundings. I think there is something in that sentence, however: the flavor of food can be amplified if the atmosphere complements it. There is something inherently homey and comforting about pupusas, and I really enjoy eating them in the comforting, homey atmosphere of the upstairs seating of Los Planes de Renderos. 

Protip: There is an upstairs. Sit there. 

Their pupusas are not fancy, but they are delicious, satisfying without being greasy, and nicely stuffed while maintaining their adorable round shape. Try the revueltas, or de queso y loroco if you're a vegetarian. Their atol de elote is wonderful on a cold day. Other favorites include their tamales, empanadas, and pasteles. 

It's cash only, and the service can be a little slow, but it's cozy, relaxing, delicious, and cheap. This place never fails to impress.
author: Aaron Y.

description:
My family and I were really excited to try this place because we heard they had "chuco". We got there around 11 opened the door and there was no one there. About 2 minutes later some lady came down the stairs and told us in a very rude tone that the closed sign was still up and she wasn't done cleaning... We stood there for a second shocked by what had just happened...As we are about to leave because we weren't obviously happy with their customer service the lady asks: "you wanna eat here? or is it to go?Yea... neither  -_-

Too bad we didn't get to try their food, but it's all good there are many other salvadorian restaurants out there that know how to treat their customers we'll be going to those instead :)
author: Yamileth O.

description: This place is incredibly dive-y.  The upstairs dining room is dark and there may be one other diner sitting in the corner, muttering to himself.  PLEASE DO NOT LET THIS DISSUADE YOU!  Or do take-out (as I noticed most of the other people did.)  Why?  Because this is BY FAR THE BEST PUPUSA I EVER ATE...the loroco pupusa especially are a REVELATION.
author: Mike B.

description: I'm not happy writing this review:( so I use to order pupusas and sopa de pata here often due to my pregnancy cravings. I would call and order for pick up, on this day I requested the same thing Sopa de pata with pata only and no pansa, the lady who answered said it was impossible and she couldn't do it with pata only. I told her I had been ordering the same soup same requests for the past 5 weekends and that's what I was given. She replies it's not her decision and that she doesn't serve the soup. I told her I was a paying customer and how I enjoyed their food, however, she replied with an attitude and very rude that she just wasn't going to do it. I told her that she was losing a loyal customer and she replied that she didn't care and that she didn't want my business anyways. I was shocked and couldn't believe this woman's attitude. I maintained my composure on the phone and said thank you. I won't be returning!
author: Selene P.

description: This place is ok, but I think la santaneca  de la mission is better.  pupupsa better filling.  the fly chicken is not great.  the chicken soap is ok.  the lengua is ok, but not great.
author: Ed Y.

description:
Made to please

This place has been around forever. Me and my folks use to come here on the regular like clockwork for about 10 years and it never disappointed. One of my fondest memories is my pop's arguing with the owner of the place about some Salvadorian soccer player and in the process almost getting us banned from this place. The pupusas are really good and their platoaños are always on point. They have two floors (at least since the last time I've been there) and their service is always great. The pupusas tend to be a little less greasy than other places which is OK but I'd prefer my pupusas dripping wet (That's what I said, get it??). If only this place was open late night so I can find my way in there after a nice night which probably includes a near death experience at Bottom's Up then that would awesome.

I suggest you don't drive here because it can be a real B trying to find parking. Be careful in parking in front of this place next to the bus stop because you will get towed. Hasn't happened to me but I've seen it happen plenty of times. 

All in all this is definitely a place you need to check out.
author: Javier G.

description: Wow! The best pupusas hands down! I heard about this place through a friend who is from El Salvador and said this is the place to go! When I got there I felt out of my comfort zone since its in a rough part of town but that wasnt stopping me from getting some great food. When you walk in there are 3 little tables and then a lady at the cashier waiting to take your order, then if you go upstairs they have a a bunch of tables and the restroom. I ordered 2 bean and cheese pupusas and a fruit drink that had chunks of apples, pineapple, and I think mango with cilantro, it was very good!! I decided to eat there and minutes later came the pupusas with a side of coleslaw.  The beans and cheese spilled out while cooking and it got a little crunchy on the sides which was so good!! The coleslaw wasn't overpowered by the vinegar like most places do.  I'm getting hungry just talking about this place.  Total hole in the wall and we all know those places are the best.  Check this one out!!!  Remember to bring CASH they don't accept credit cards.
author: Alexis G.

description:
BEST PUPUSAS EVER!!!!!! i come here often and I always get the same thing... pupusa ruvuelta (pork, bean, and cheese). Pupusas are usually always greasy but these aren't. They are so tasty and made to order. The filling is so good and cooked to perfection. I am a loyal customer here because the food is never a disappointment. I've also had the fried platanos with sour cream and beans and they are so friggggn good!

Just a heads up... the pupusas take a little while to make so be prepared for slower service. But, it is well worth the wait. They are the best pupusas I've ever had. You can't eat just one especially with the cortido on top YUM!!
author: Gabriella G.

description: I've been going here since I was a little girl. Amazing Salvadorian food! Yes it is cash only which is a bummer & sometimes service can be a tad slow since there is little staff but doesn't stop me from coming here. They serve great food and its cozy. Best pupusas and atole de elote! I am getting hungry just thinking of it. Enjoy!
author: Maria S.

description: Been coming here for years. These are as close to my Abuelas (grandmother) Pupusas as it gets. Less than $2 for a Pupusas. I always call ahead and order for pick up. They are made to order so it is a wait. Must try they are the real deal.
author: C. M.

description: I've eaten here before and really enjoyed the food. They are slow but tonight was RIDICULOUS ! My rice and beans were cold. I meant fridge cold! And the waitress would be gone for loooong periods of time. My husband had to go to the kitchen himself to get the food they forgot to bring to the table. Bad bad bad
author: Rita B.

description:
This is a cash only, two-story hole in the wall, offering perfectly assembled Pupusas Ruvueltas (Meat, cheese and beans with cabbage slaw and hot sauce toppings). 

The horchata, although different in comparison with the Mexican style I tend to receive is a necessary accompaniment to a plate of piled up pupusas resembling pancake stacks. 

The food is hearty, cheap and tasty. I had a big group of 10 friends from an earlier 49ers tailgate and there were no complaints from them as there was plenty of room for us upstairs. The service was good and the food came out pretty fast. When I'm in the neighborhood, I know I will return to this homey establishment. 

The only thing to consider is, where are you gonna park?
author: Dennis S.

description:
Fresh pupusas made to order. This was my first times eating these little corn masa pockets oozing with cheese. For under $2 (around 1.70 - 1.75 depending on what filling you want) a piece, the price cannot be beat! They taste like a little quesadilla made with corn flower. My personal favorite was the con queso y loroco. I also tried the carnitas, and the carnitas and beans. The loroco had more cheese and therefore much more deliciousness. The pupusas also came with a side of vinegary coleslaw and a red tomato sauce (a little too thin to be salsa?). The sauce went good with the pork and bean pupusas because they had less cheese and were definitely a bit drier. 

If you are going to order to go, call in ahead. It's about a 20 minute wait as they are made fresh. It can be easy to miss if you are looking for Los Planes De Renderos, its located on a side street of mission with a big sign that says Pupuseria y Restaurant.
author: Colin H.

description: Omg these are the popusas I will love forever! Been to many popuserias around town, and none will top these! Precaution; slow service. Call ahead of time. Take them to go.
author: Elisa S.

description:
Great service. We didn't realize the place was closing, but the waitress still took the time to take our orders and was really patient with us.

Food was average, in my opinion.  The pupusas I've had in LA are a lot better.

The place felt a little dive-y, which is great.  I would definitely take my family here.
author: Bryant C.

description:
I've been coming here for the past 5 years, ever since my friend introduced me to pupusas. I'd like to think that pupusas are a heartier version of a quesadilla. 

Los Planes makes the best pupusas I've ever had (well, I've only tried a few different places). We usually call in our order and get them filled with meat. I like how they are always hot when we pick them up, freshly made with cheese oozing out of it. I especially like eating it with their cabbage and "cocktail sauce." 

I think the cheese pupusas are cheaper at under $2 but the ones with meat are about $3/each. 

Again, this place is cash only as many have mentioned but so are a lot of places around the Mission. Nothing new.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Affordable, delicious, and filling...the only thing I found awkward was the seating.  Looks like the only place to sit are the three small tables when you first enter.  No worries there is a whole seating area upstairs, it seems off at first.
There is a bit of waiting to be served, but as soon as your pupusas arrive you will get over the wait time.
The food is delicious, from the platanos fritos,  empanadas, and pupusas; best part it's affordable..thumbs up!
author: Alejandro G.

description: Great place for PUPUSAS!! and las AGUAS frescas . Las Muchachas are very friendly , the food is nice and HOT. I been coming to los Planes since I was 10. and this place has not change since ,  if your ever in the area Is a MUST.
author: Gigi H.

description:
Based on the reviews on Yelp, I convinced myself to give this place a try without having too high of an expectation. I mean, honestly, a pupusa is a pupusa right? How can a stuffed maize-dough tortilla from one location taste any different than that of another; besides, of course, the amount of oil used by each? Boy was I given a slap in the face when I tried Los Planes. I was dead wrong in my assumption, and was so overwhelmingly satisfied with not only the really low prices, but also at how fresh and delicious the pupusas were. This place is good eats. 

Now, I'm not Salvadorean, so by no means does my judgment of the authenticity of Salvadorean cuisine hold any validity whatsoever. However, as a previous poster commented, this place is filled to the brim with native Salvadoreans (I do speak fluent Spanish and can distinguish the accents/diction of several Latin American cultures), and that in itself speaks loads on the restaurant's behalf.

It is a hole-in-the-wall establishment, which may turn-off the bombardment of hipsters and yuppies recently acquired by the Mission District, but this is an authentic Mission-style restaurant, with authentic Mission-style food, and fuck me is it delicious.

I would definitely love to come back here, very soon, and recommend this place to anyone who loves them some pupusas! It may be a bit difficult to find, so in case you are having trouble, just note to yourself: Mission Street & Persia Ave, on the right side of the block with the uphill slope, right next to the Salvadorean bakery. 

Enjoy!
author: Bryan H.

description: Being a small business owner myself, there's nothing worse then having to post a negative review for a small business owner.  Customer service, honesty and integrity are of utmost importance when running a small business.  My 12 y/o daughter and I decided to venture out and try a new restaurant we love Salvadorean food and found Los Plane De Renderos Pupuseria on Yelp.  We entered the small restaurant and sat ourselves as no one came to greet us.  The place is quite small maybe 14 x 10 feet and we were two of four customers in the Restaurant mind you there are only approx 6 small tables it's not like they were busy.  We waited to order and finally my daughter got up and went to the register to get someones attention and placed the order, she ordered a $12 dish of Lengua and Salsa and I ordered $6.50 dish we also ordered two Horchata's listed on the menu as $2.50 each.  It took a long time to prepare the food, it finally came and was decent but nothing to write home about.  No one ever came out to check on us so my daughter once again went to the register to ask for our check.  The lady told her "That will be $32.20" My daughter and I had already calculated the bill to be $23.50 + tax & tip so I said do you mean $23.50?  She said "No $32.20 you ordered large horchata's and they cost $5.50 each"   We did not order larger horchata's we asked for 2 horchata's as there was no size designation on the menu and they did not ask us what size when we ordered.  The menu just reads horchata $2.50.  The lady said we changed the prices and its not on the menu.   I paid the $32.20 I'm still kicking myself, I left the restaurant feeling cheated and reverse discriminated against.  I will never go back here or recommend this place to anyone else there are many other Salvadorean places to visit.  It's sad thou, being a SF resident and a business owner who showers there customers with customer service I never expect to be treated badly or unfairly by other small business owners as your customers our the life blood of your business.   I drove home thinking this lady ripped off a potential repeat customer $6 almost as if to give us the middle finger.  I will never go back to this restaurant, save yourself a trip there are many other great Salvadorean restaurants in the city.
author: Eileen C.

description: This is the best pupusa in the city. You will notice that the poor reviews are from whitebread candy-asses who expect to be waited on hand and foot. Do not expect quality service, expect a fucking awesome pupusa. Throw your pride away before entering, and just think about the tasty pupusas. If they sneer at you, just ignore it, and keep in mind why you're there. Tasty. Pupusas. There is no ambiance. The waitress has a permanent baleful eye. Sometimes I even think that the servers are slightly racist against white people. And yet, I still give this place five stars, because they have some tasty fucking pupusas. Seriously, get your priorities straight before you come in here, this is not a service oriented establishment, this is a pupusa oriented establishment. Los Planes De Renderos Pupuseria is King.
author: Joseph O.

description:
They don't accept cards, cash only. 
I used to love this place but sometimes you go upstairs get a table and they don't even notice they have customers waiting. I walked out once with my sister and will never go back there.
author: Olga G.

description: RUDE!!! make sure you get your change, because I didn't get mine!!! this hole in the wall doesn"t deserve any stars..........  beware........ there are many other places that are great in the hood.
author: Jerry W.

description:
I knew pupusas were cheap, but this place is super cheap. True hole-in-the-wall. Pupusas are around $1.70 each. I ordered two pupusa and after tip and tax, just $5. The lady was even nice enough to let us pay separately.

I ordered two loroco pupusa. They was very cheesey. My friends had the pupusas with meat and actually preferred those as those were not as cheesey as the loroco one. Overall, very good for the price.

Cash only.
author: Angela T.

description:
The best Salvadoria food that I have found in the city. We tried the cheese, pork and refried bean Pupusa and it was really good! I had the flautas as my meal and my bf had the chicken enchiladas. The refried beans had a great flavor compared to any I've ever had before. The avocados which came with my meal were really fresh and the enchilada sauce was great tasting too. 

Will definitely be going back.
author: Jennifer P.

description: I'm giving this place 4 stars because the food is pretty great, the service on the other hand is the WORST service of any salvadorian restaurant I have ever been to.
author: Adree A.

description: Best place for Papusas that I have ate so far. I had it in other places am haven't been really interested until I have had one here. Now I'm sooo into papusas. Very authentic and tasty! It's a moms n pops type of place but well worth going to! I haven't tasted anything else in their menu cause I'm stuck on their papusas.
author: Joce B.

description: The only good thing about this place was the salsa. $2 pupusas is a good deal but they seemed smaller than I'm used to. More cheese than beans or pork. Also very hard to decipher which was beans and which was chicaron. Cabbage was mostly watery and not spicy. Blehhh. Left much to be desired.
author: Ann Z.

description: I get my puposa fix here and it always hits the spot. I get stuffed from simply two with the accompanying cabbage/ dip. They make it hot on the spot and as others have said, cash only!
author: Karen H.

description: This hole-in-the-wall restaurant serves some cheap good sized pupusas. Pupusas remind me of a cheese pizza except the dough is more glutinous and filling so I really only need one to feel quite full. The horchata was pretty good, the maranon drink was too sweet (hurts the throat) but the tamarindo was perfect. I thought it was slightly bitter at first (though pleasant) but then as I had more it was more sweet to me but not overly sweet. I would definitely have tamarindo again. Next time I would like a bean and pork pupusa combination. Service is quite slow here. Better know what you want to order when you order because you won't know when the lady will make it back around next. I enjoyed the el salvadorean experience.
author: Helen L.

description: Pupusas are to die for, and the soup is like your Tia made it at home. ;) authentic is an understatement.
author: Stefanie A.

description:
I really wanna like this place, really I do.
Me and my mom used to come here and sit in the upstairs and order pupusas. And back in those days it was delicious! This was the only place me and my mom would go to. And my mom knows what real pupusas from El Salvador are supposed to taste, seeing as how she was born there. But I went back a while ago and this place has lost its flair.Maybe its because I discovered Los Guanacos and now it can't compare, but I mean wow. The pupusa was so dry. The masa was not at all how it should taste, and the combination of cheese and beans just wasn't at all what I wanted. The beans were like clay. I'll go back, and hope for the best because this place reminds me of when I was a little girl with her mom. SO lets hope for the best, wish me luck!
author: Peeta B.

description: The place rocks .  Food is delish .  Good service .  Clean .
author: Mary E.

description: $1.80 for the freshest shredded pork and cheese pupusa? Why yes I'll order 5! Greasy goodness at it's best.
author: Alexa M.

description:
Definitely the best pupusas in the bay area. Try the 'revueltas' and 'agua de tamarindo'

Definitivamente las mejores pupusas que he probado. Las revueltas y el agua de tamarindo son mi favoritos
author: Jose G.

description:
After passing by MANY times, I finally stopped in and am glad I did.  I was craving some pupusas, and I see this place always has people inside.  It may look very small from the outside, but there is a second floor with plenty of tables.

I had some Pupusas de Chicharron Y Queso, (pork and cheese) and Pupusas de Queso, Chicharron y Frijoles, (the same with beans.)  They are super cheap at less than $2 each and all come with red sauce and cabbage slaw.  I don't know what that "slaw" is called, but it was good.  The masa was chock full of beans, cheese and meat, grilled until golden and gooey.  Next time I want to try the Loroco.  Two will fill you up. so if you just have an Abe in your wallet, you can eat here.  

Traditional plates are available, such as Bistec Encebollado, (Steak with onions), Tamales, and other plates sound really good too, but cost around $9

Since this is one of my first ventures into Pupusas, I am anxious to try more to see how they fare elsewhere.

One thing ... CASH only.
author: Michael M.

description:
8 pupusas, an orchata, and a hot chocolate all for $23. Whaaaaaaaaat??

I liked pupusas before, and now I absolutely love them. It doesn't get any better than this (not that I know of anyway). The dough is thin and crispy and there is a generous amount of filling. We got all pupusas revueltas and they were soooooo flavorful. The place I used to go to before (not in SF) oftentimes made the dough too thick and did not include very much filling, but now I know better and what pupusas can be. One is enough to make me extremely full, and at around $2-3 each, this absolutely cannot make me broke! They also provided a bowl of salsa and some chips at the beginning of the meal where were also very yummm. Spicy but not too spicy, even for me.

Their orchata is a Salvadorean version, very different from the Mexican version. There's something in it that makes it weird...but in a good way. It was still very tasty and made me think of mung bean for some reason. And their hot chocolate? Or chocolate con leche? I'm not sure what it was but it was BOMB. It was seriously chocolate con leche, mostly chocolate with some milk in it.

This place is absolute win. I have to go back since I live so closeby.

edit: forgot we ordered a tamale as well. i didn't try it, but my friends didn't really like it. the preparation method was different from what they did and they said it was soggier. mom's home cooking trumps restaurant food sometimes, plus it was salvadorean tamale rathern than mexican.
author: Victoria L.

description: I love the pupusas here! My favorite is "Queso con Loroco" (Cheese with a Veggie that looks like Zucchini). Their "caldo de res" is off the hook. It reminds me of the way my momma used to make it for us as kids. It's also my usual weekend hang out when I am suffering from a severe hang-over. The grease really hits the spot. I would give it a 4 stars but it really needs "An Extreme Makeover: Restaurant Edition"
author: Carla F.

description:
I'm hopelessly addicted to the pork, cheese and refried bean papusas.  Dab a little sour creme on those bad boys and for a $1.60 it's perfection.  Minus one star for the slow cook time (takes like 20 min for an order, so always call ahead) and the dry plantains.  My man loves their slaw.  MUST try other items like their soup and that hot coco lookin' drink. SO GOOD!!!

I have no idea what their hours are and I always end up double parking when I roll through but whatever, definitely recommend this joint.
author: Margaret L.

description:
I have been reluctant to review this place, because I don't want anyone else to know about it.  It's perfectly, 100% Salvadoran.  Not Salvadoran and Mexican.  Not Salvadoran and Nigaraguan.   Not Salvadoran and anything else...just perfectly Salvadoran.

It's a dive and it bothers me that the pictures on the wall are crooked.  But if you're looking for the best Salvadoran food in San Francisco, you can find it here.
author: Kimberley A.

description: Last time I was in California I got myself some great El Salvadorean food from here. The service was pretty good and the establishment had a second floor in case customers were plentiful. A great place to get some food if you are in San Francisco.
author: Carlos H.

description:
I love pupusas.  For those that are unfamiliar with Salvadorian cuisine a pupusa is somewhat similar to a quesadilla but utilizes thick corn cakes instead of thin flour tortillas.  The middle of a pupusa can be filled with a variety of things but are most commonly seen with cheese, beans, or carnitas or a combination of all or each on their own.  

The thick corn cakes are then pan-seared until the ingredients are hot or melted and when it is eaten it is usually accompanied by a special cabbage salsa called Curtido.  This type of Salvadorian 'slaw' at Los Planes is great and tastes just like my aunt makes.  

Now about Los Planes......it is a very very very tiny little hole in the wall restaurant but the food here is very authentic and delicious.  There is no real seating downstairs but there is a smaller area upstairs if you insist on eating in but i wouldn't recommend it.  It is better to take out and enjoy the comforts of home.  

Given that I can't really eat these greasy cakes of goodness all the time I must do so sparingly when I get the chance and thus I choose my pupusas carefully.  I LOVE the bean and cheese combination the best and I completely smother it in curtido.  The crunchiness of the cabbage combined with the crispy and soft pupusa is a definitive experience of El Salvadorian food.  Beware of dripping grease while eating this tasty dish as we all know that oil is the WORST stainer.  

I wouldn't change los planes for anything because i appreciate and love hole in the wall places.  the best part is that the owners don't skimp on the curtido and the prices are great.  

While you wait for your pupusas take a trip next door to the Salvadorian panaderia next door (bakery).  They have sweet cake and cookies that are to die for.  Check out my review on Pacita's Salvadorian Bakery

If you come to SF and want to try the real Salvadorian pupusa go to Los Planes.  Enjoy!!
author: Crista Y.

description: This is my second trip to the San Francisco area, the first time I did the typical tourist things.  This time around, I asked my friend to bring me to their favorite places to eat...this was another must go see place!  And I must say it is well worth it, I love going to places that all workers are actually from the place of the cuisine they are selling.
author: Joy A.

description:
Whenever people ask me "Where do you get the best pupusas in the city?" I always recommend Planes de Renderos!

Coming from a Salvadoran family, trust me its hard to find even "decent" pupuserias sometimes, but THIS place in my opinion has some of the best in SF. Been eating their pupusas  since I was a kid

Big, thick juicy pupusas of various kinds (Revueltas, frijoles, queso con loroco, chicharron, you name it!), these are STACKED with flavor you won't find anywhere else. And the Curtido (Cabbage) is amazing too! If you order out, they always give plenty of it along with Salsa

True, this place is more like a take-out place/dive and they DO tend to forget customers upstairs (trust me I've been in many of those situations), but I do not complain because the pupusas are that good haha The platanos fritos and the Empanadas are also delicious mmmm

And honestly, there are A LOT of dives in SF that only take cash, not just this place, so always come prepared, especially if you plan to eat on Mission, OK!
author: Cesar C.

description:
Very spare, primitive place, so don't go expecting a lot of fru-fru atmosphere. Also in a sort of obscure part of the Excelsior, so keep an eye on the shadows at night. However, that said, the restaurant has a friendly atmosphere.

But, the food was excellent. The menu for papusas is fairly limited, but the papusas are great. We also had the sweet corn soup - sweet, but great. And the plantains...that might have been the best of all. Don't tell your cardiologist.

No beer or alcohol served.
author: Mister K.

description: I love their papusas. I always get their cheese, re fried beans, and shredded pork ones!! I have been going here for 2 years and I have tried several places but this is my favorite so far. They're so cheap too $1.79 each or something. Really reasonable for anytime of the day! I have come to eat here for breakfast, lunch and dinner!! I bring all my friends here and I would recommend this place to everyone.  Parking is sometimes hard depending what time you go, but this is my go to place! I haven't tried anything else on the menu but if you do come here you must try their papusas!
author: Liana D.

description:
Oh. My. God.

I ate my first pupusas here today after hearing about the wonderful morsels of Salvadoran deliciousness that they serve here. Every word I've heard is true. YUM!

The menu is larger than I expected, but the second page is all that matters. They serve about 5 varieties of pupusas here and the ones filled with pork are by far the most juicy and most flavorful.

I ordered mine for an early dinner with an horchata (less cinnamon-y than others and a bit chocolate-y) and was full with 2 pupusas. The cabbage that they serve with the pupusas is absolutely wonderful in terms of flavor and texture. The cabbage is soft and easy to eat, but not so soft as to make you question its freshness. The salsa they serve is watery, but has enough flavor to really enhance your pupusas.

The actual restaurant is a bit grungy, but just bring hand sanitizer and you're golden.

The MUNI 29 line rolled by while we were upstairs, so that's certainly an option for getting to this restaurant.

For those who go without a guide, you sit down first and the owner will find you. Grab menus off of whatever tables you find to decide what you want. When you're done, head for the kitchen and pay in cash. Head on over to the Salvadoran bakery next door for a guava filled shortbread cookie or a tres leches cake.

Total cost of my two pupasas + horchata? $5

====

Rubric: 5 = Mindblowing 4 = Excellent 3 = I see the charm 2 = Disappointing 1 = Never again
author: Eric K.

description: Pretty good pupusa. Not fancy dining. There are 3 small tables when you enter, then there's also dining upstairs. I thought the pupusas were 1.75 each, however when i ordered 2, it was a little over $4. Unless there was a charge I wasn't aware of. Cash only. No credit cards.
author: Robin L.

description:
This place is TINY.  It's got about 4 2-person tables stuck down in the entry room where the cash register is, and additional seating upstairs (those waitresses are hardcore climbing those up and down all day with big trays of food).  I haven' had a TON of pupusas in my time, but from the one's that I've had (which were all highly recommended by friends), these were up there taste-wise.  They come out piping hot and are served with free chips and the radish/sauce stuff you get to smother the things in before you gobble them down.  If you're in a big rush it may not be the best place to stop by since parking can be rough, and since it's run by a staff of about 3-4 (only noe waitress usually), you may have to wait 15 mins or so for your food.

If you're in the mood for a little cozy spot where you can have a chat with a friend and down some hot, tasty pupusas, this place is great!  They're like less than 2$ each too!
author: Matt M.

description:
if you're looking for a 1.70 to 1.75 costing papusa...this is the place for you.

i've enjoyed their food and they were kind people.

the papusa itself is stuffed with cheese, thick and enough meat that i could taste it and enjoy it.  

my only issue and maybe its because i took it to go...well, maybe not.  bottom line.  i had very bitter tasting cabbage on top.  the hot sauce was good which helped counter the bitterness of the cabbabe.

overall its okay for the price.  take it to go or sit down its a nice place.

if you're going for taste and quality over anything else?  then pay the 3 dollars on a saturday or sunday at the farmers market on Alemany.  well, sunday is a flea market but the same people are there.  I don't remember their name and i used to go there EVERY WEEKEND TO GET A PAPUSA but they raised their prices from 2.50 to 3.00 and thats just too expensive...though when you taste it...ITS WORTH IT.  I have to go and remember their name because thats how i want EVERY PAPUSA TO TASTE!
author: Bing D.

description:
Food:  BEST PUPUSAS IN TOWN!  Super cheesy, crispy crust and never too greasy.  The platanos melt in your mouth......yucca  and pork are tangy, crispy and super tasty......fried fish is fresh and out of this world.

Decor: Ghetto  chic.....actually just ghetto. 

Overall impression:  Supreme Salvadorian food,  but I wish they would put some money into their interior decorating. I bet ya that some people are scared off  by their looks.   Hmmmm,  maybe I should apply to remodel their place.
author: consuelo r.

description: One of the Best pupusas in San Francisco. I am a Salvadorean and I really know what is good and what not. These pupusas have good taste, they are big in size with a lot food inside and NOT greasy. Not been greasy is one of the main reason that makes me comeback to this place.
author: A A.

description: I've tried lots of pupuseria and this place hits the spot...the best yet.
author: Emilio J.

description:
so far the best pupusas in the city that my bf and i have tried!  they fry them with a bit of oil so they're a bit greasy which definitely adds more flavor [not to the point where they're unhealthy though]

we always get mixed pupusas and they're only $1.70 each!  i love their fruit drink which has a mixture of apples, pineapples, and all sorts of other fruits in it.  that costs somewhere around $2.25 but definitely refreshing and worth getting.  they also served chips and salsa one early afternoon we went but we stopped by for dinner one night and they didn't have the drink or chips and salsa so we're not sure if it's a lunch thing?

definitely better than the other pupusas places we've tried!  we're so glad we found this hole in the wall.  it's actually very clean upstairs [which is where we've eaten the last 3 times we've been here].  ordering was a bit tricky because there's no real cash register so order downstairs if you can and then you can just go upstairs.  they bring you food and you pay as you leave.  

a meal for 2 people under $10 including tip.  i think that's rare these days.

4 mixed pupusas
fruit drink
free chips and salsa
author: J K.

description: Just had dinner ter.pupusas r HELLA good.service not so GOOD!!!
author: Moe M.

description: this little hole in the wall restaurant has the best pupusas and horchata!!!! just like my grandma's :)
author: Sandra D.

description: the pupusas here are really good. I have them almost every weekend. You should give them a try. If you have a taste for food from central american please check it out.
author: Dee Z.

description: Pretty good pupusas, a little on the greasy side though. Can't go wrong with their beans, platanos and crema. It is a little out of the way, but pretty darn good. If you are in the area, try it. Cash only...not much cash necessary though.
author: Michael W.

description: Been coming here as far back as I can remember. There's tons of Salvadorian restaurants on Mission, but this one is gooood.. Very cheap and very tasty. Good assortment of different types of Salvadorian food. There's also a bakery next door so you can snatch up some breakfast rolls  . (The bakery is also Salvadorian). I highly recommend this place. Be prepared, however.. Ugly on the outside and on the inside.. I like to think they spend their money on the food and not decorations.. :)
author: Grace G.

description: amazing, one of my new favorite restaurants!  I tried it for the first time the other day after reviewing yelp so I could find more places around my house, soooo good!  I would have never found it w/o yelp, it is a total hole in the wall that is well priced and such good food.  I am a horchata lover, and theirs is to die for w/ the chocolate in it!  I got way too much food for under $40.  I highly recommend this place!
author: Taylor W.

description: I love this place, awesome pupusas.  I just hate the location because you have to find street parking and its way out there, practically Daly City.  This place is old school, I remember going as a kid with our family.  I like the upstairs part to it too.  You can't go wrong with any food item here.  I love the platanos with frijoles y crema.  If in the neighborhood make sure to go there and enjoy all their specialties.  Yum!
author: La C.

description: as a Salvadorean raised in SF, i became a frequent customer at a very young age. this is by far my favorite place to go pick up pupusas revueltas in the entire city! the restaurant is a hole in the wall but the waitresses are extremely nice, although they may take a while to take an order or bring drinks to you (specifically when sitting at a table on the second floor). the horchata is delicious and the atol de elote is to die for but some people may have a problem with location, size, or ambiance of the place since its not exactly amazing. to me, all that matters is quality of food and i give it two thumbs up. family and i come here all the time and will continue to do so til the place shuts down! =]
author: Natalie F.

description: NIce friendly servers.  I had the papusa quesos and papusa revolta as well as some empanadas.   Everything was fresh and delicious.
author: Mike J.

description: We gave this place a try the other night and were pleasantly surprised at the quality of the food. The ambience is definitely nothing to speak of, and the sticky plastic table coverings prompted us to take our order to go, but the food was delicious. We had the bistec encebollado (about $10), an assortment of pupusas (about $2 each), and an empanada ($2.50). The bistec was remarkably lean and tender, the beans and rice that accompanied were tasty, and the corn tortillas were plentiful and delicious. The pupusas were also delicious and quite large, and came with a tasty red sauce and cabbage slaw (almost like a Latin kim-chi, flavored with chili and vinegar). The empanada was not at all what I expected, being more familiar with Argentinan style spicy meat empanadas. Instead it was a pastry made of mashed plantains and cream, which was a perfect way to finish our meal. For $20, we ended up with a huge amount of food for two people. We will definitely be going back to Los Planes.
author: Brian H.

description: Delicious pupusas con queso y frijoles, and con queso y loroco. Fried plantains are some of the best I've had. Only drawback is whether you eat in or take-out be prepared to wait. They take the time to prepare a delicious meal, but you will wait for it.
author: Bob B.
